awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: 3D Printing of Civil Infrastructure Materials with Controlled Microstructural Architectures
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaborative project is to use additive manufacturing (3D printing) to engineer the microstructure of cement-based materials and fabricate cement-based structures with otherwise unachievable, controlled local composition of the material and spatial arrangement of its components. The goal of the research is to understand the major factors controlling the 3D printing process of cement-based materials and how to design interfacial interactions between printed filament layers and between filament inclusions and solid matrix phases. Though the use of additive manufacturing, the proposed research project has the potential to enable significant progress in the fields of high-performance infrastructure materials by providing materials that exhibit paradigm-shifting properties allowing new functionalities that are not achievable with existing materials. Ultimately, the 3-D printing processes will enable the fabrication of light-weight and modular structures and buildings for rapid deployment in cases of natural disasters and product applications wherein cement-based materials have not previously been competitive. The educational component will leverage existing programs of each of the three institutions and includes the development of instructional materials for undergraduate and graduate students and research opportunities for a diverse group of undergraduate students.

The goal of this collaborative research is to fundamentally understand (1) the intertwined mechanisms between chemistry, printed filament layer solidification, and 3D printing successive-layering-deposition process conditions and (2) the interfacial interactions between printed layers that control the bonding mechanism. 3-D printing is anticipated to enable the controlled spatial variation of material properties through continuous gradients in functional components. Experimental investigations of the filament layer solidification process and of the interfacial characteristics will be integrated with computational analysis, including molecular dynamics simulations of the molecular scale structure, energetics, and mechanical properties of the inter-filament and interfaces to unravel the physico-chemo-mechanical mechanisms that underpin the processing/manufacturing-microstructure-property relationship of the architectured materials. The research will (1) provide a molecular to nanoscale picture of the chemo-mechanical interactions between filament layers and between the filament inclusions and matrix interfaces, (2) identify key aspects of the structure at interfaces necessary to enable refinement of surfaces and printing media chemistry, and (3) provide insights into the development of a new approach to understanding and developing cementitious systems.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
One of the current challenges in the additive manufacturing (AM) process of cementitious materials is the presence of heterogeneities and weak interfaces, mostly produced by the extrusion process.  Contrary to the commonly adopted approach (which is to eliminate these heterogeneous interfaces), we focused our contribution on harnessing those relatively weak interfaces by employing novel architectures (some bioinspired) that promote delocalization of cracks propagation and local zones of failure. Applying this concept to 3D printed hardened cement paste (hcp) elements, we found that these architectures generate unique damage mechanisms, which allow inherently brittle hcp materials to attain flaw-tolerant properties and novel performance characteristics without sacrificing strength. This delocalization eventually lead to a spread of damage that adds to the energy dissipation around the damage zone, therefore, increasing toughness.

 

We have demonstrated that AM and control of the architecture of the elements can lead to novel behaviors of cement-based materials such as hardened cement pastes and mortars. These behaviors, observed in compliant design prisms and Bouligand architectures, demonstrate new potential for engineering the performance of cement-based materials. In Bouligand architectures, we demonstrated that the presence of the heterogeneous interfaces is not necessarily detrimental to the overall mechanical performance of the printed element. Rather, these interfaces can provide mechanisms leading to novel responses such as an increased deflection, and enhanced work of fracture. It must be noted that the development of these enhanced properties certainly depends on the ability of the material to spread the damage over larger volumes. To further explore opportunities provided by architectured cement paste and mortar materials, we carried out several detailed analyses of the intertwined relationships between processing-induced heterogeneities, interfacial strength, ink properties (cement hydration, rheology, chemistry, and formulation), architectural parameters, and microstructural characteristics of the filaments. This project lied the foundations of our next research focus, which is up-scaling to 3D printing of large scale concrete structures.

 

In terms of broader impact, our team at Purdue focused on mentorship and career development for a postdoc, three PhD students and several undergraduate students. Our team, including the PhD student, developed an undergraduate level course at Lyles School of Civil Engineering, and established new links to the industry for tech transfer. Namely, the team closely worked with RCAM Technologies as part the NSF INTERN program that provided additional support for our PhD students. The team acquired (on a loan from RCAM technologies) an ABB 4600 robotic arm to support our efforts toward 3D printing of large scale concrete structures. In terms of dissemination, our work has already been published in several papers and reports, and has been presented at key international conferences and workshops together with the teams at Vanderbilt University and Tenneessee Tech. Furthermore, some of these published papers are already gaining several citations, indicating that the work is getting attention in the concrete and other communities. We have also successfully obtained additional funding through the NSF AccelNet program in collaboration with other universities to further disseminate knowledge related to concrete 3D printing.

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2021
Modified by: Pablo D Zavattieri
